Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: How to get Martian water on our telescope?
Input.posts:
Lecture 4, about the detection of water on martian spectrum immediately spawned interest in my amateur astronomy activities.. I have a slit spectrograph, capable of resolving 30km/s at 6500A, I also have a CCD camera that has a Quantum Efficiency of 50% at 8000A. So I immediately thought of replicating the detection of water on Mars by Spinrad, Münch and Kaplan in 1963's paper!... Even though I only have an 11' telescope... (It would have been nicer to do last year, as it would make the 50th anniversary, but Mars was not in the second quadrature (red shift) last year! ;-) So perhaps I'm still in time!) But I have a few problems! - First: My spectrograph is a Lithrow design with a tiltable 2400 lines/mm grating. To get to 8000A I need to tilt my grating by 80 degrees. The grating is 50mm wide, which means it will only cover 17mm of the collimated light beam reaching it (which is larger than that) and I will loose light, apart from the lack of efficiency of a grating this much tilted! - looking at 8000A, I will need an order filter, to make sure the wavelengths I am getting are in fact 8000 and not twice of 4000A from the second order diffraction of 'blue'. I don't have such IR-pass filter, yet.. It would be nice if I could use other wavelengths, even if I need to take care when calibrating spectra, removing the Earth's water signature... I figure Earth's water is always in the same place on the spectrum, so a spectrum from Mars now (opposition) and from July (quadrature), when normalized and divided by each other should show features where they differ (Doppler-shifted lines).. ...Assuming humidity in the air did not vary from now to July (very unlikely). But I can remove Earth's water from each spectrum using an A or B star (with clean spectrum in that part) for reference. Because of this, perhaps I could use the water vapor lines between 6400 and 6600 A, even though those are strong on Earth... I suspect the authors of the original work did not do any math on spectra because photographic plates weren't as math-friendly as digital spectra :)... - so might I use the 6400-6600 region? Will there not be interference of the sun reflecting of the surface of Mars in these wavelengths, like it happened with the determination of martian temperature? The fact that I might consider two spectra of Mars, at different times, with the martian ground illuminated by a different angle makes me wonder on this. Also, should I try to take spectra when the same patch of martian surface is facing the Earth? - are there any better (lower than 8000 A) water absorption lines to use for this? - Am I right in thinking Mars will be at last Quadrature in mid July? - I am curious if I can detect any difference in H2O from the south pole to the equator as I can orient my spectrograph slit with the N/S of Mars... This sounds like an interesting summer project :) I hope this course doesn't give me many more such ideas, or I will run out of time to undertake them...

Instructor's Post
I don't know the locations of all water lines off the top of my head, but the place to start exploring would be the National Solar Observatory (NSO) atlas of the sun. I have an old hard copy on my shelves but it all must be available online these days. Every spectral line is identified, including the ones caused by terrestrial absorption! Also, July sounds about right to me -- pretty much any time it is ~straight overhead in the early evening or late morning sky works!

Input.threadtitle: My theory of Mars being responsible for creating our Moon
Input.posts:
My variation on the theory of how our Moon was formed. I am speculating the planet Mars was originally about the size of the Earth, with an atmosphere similar to Earth, and liquid surface water of lakes, rivers and possibly oceans, and much warmer than it is now. It had a magnetic field, which combined with a greater mass, provided Mars with a magnetic field. This could be about 3.5 to 4 billion years ago. Mars was in a better condition for hosting life at that time than Earth was. Then, a massive planetoid slammed into Mars, ripping the planet almost in half. I suspect the region known as Hellas Planitia was where the giant planetoid impacted the Martian landscape. Like a bullet hitting Mars, I call this the 'entry wound'. And I suspect that a massive remaining chunk of the planetoid 'bullet' continued on through the Martian core until it struck beneath the other side and caused the Tharsis Bulge, not quite managing an 'exit wound', but helping to create the giant Martian mountain (approx. 21 km high) Olympus Mons, plus the triad of mountains - Arsia Mons, Pavonis Mons and Ascraeus Mons. (I do love the apparent symmetry of the triangular arrangement of the four mountains of the Tharsis Bulge...with Arsia, Pavonis and Ascraeus forming the base, and Olympus the apex. Isn't it just wonderful!) The tremendous impact not only stripped away most of the Martian atmosphere, and evaporated probably most of the surface water into space, but also splitting open a giant gash known as Valles Marineris. In addition the core at the centre of Mars was damaged so that it could no longer generate the planet's magnetic field, which is why Mars doesn't have one today. The impact ejected massive chunks and debris...two of which remained as the satellites, Deimos and Phobos, in Martian orbits. Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Plate tectonics is the coolest. I just wanted to add that you need water to act as a lubricant, to lower the viscosity of the lower lithosphere/upper asthenosphere, so that slab pull can occur at trenches. Technically, it doesn't need to be water, just something that lowers viscosity. I'm not sure what the lubricant could be besides water though. As I understand it, the presence of water lowers a rock/mineral's viscosity because it breaks up the bonds in the mineral and weakens its structure. Also, no one really knows why plates exist in the first place. There are a lot of theories, to be sure, and I'm not sure which is the leading contender right now. It's believed that having a lithosphere that can break up into plates correlates with the strength of the lithosphere. So we don't see plates on Venus because the lithosphere is too thick/dry/strong. We see plates on Earth because the lithospheric strength is just right. Another factor could be the temperature gradient (1) across the core-mantle boundary and (2) across the lithosphere. Here's the best way I can think of to explain this (1) On Earth, we know that out core is convecting because we have a magnetic field. The fact that the core is convecting means that heat is being transferred out of the core and into the mantle. Apparently the energy flux out of the core and into the mantle is great enough that the mantle convects as well. A convecting mantle helps the lithospheric plates moves (though it is unclear if the convection mechanism is whole-mantle or two-layer). (2) On Venus, the surface temperature is so high that the temperature gradient across the lithosphere (or what would be a plate) is too small to have any effect on the strength or buoyancy of the lithosphere. So, to my understanding, if any of these conditions are not met (i.e., if there is no surface water, the wrong lithospheric strength, no convecting core, no convecting mantle, no large temperature gradient across the crust), then plate tectonics won't happen. Plate tectonics is tricky though, since we're working with a sample size of 1! Note: Lithosphere=crust+upper mantle where heat is transferred via conduction. Asthenosphere=mantle where heat is transferred via convection.

Technically, it doesn't need to be water, just something that lowers viscosity. I'm not sure what the lubricant could be besides water though. As I understand it, the presence of water lowers a rock/mineral's viscosity because it breaks up the bonds in the mineral and weakens its structure. Also, no one really knows why plates exist in the first place. There are a lot of theories, to be sure, and I'm not sure which is the leading contender right now. It's believed that having a lithosphere that can break up into plates correlates with the strength of the lithosphere. So we don't see plates on Venus because the lithosphere is too thick/dry/strong. We see plates on Earth because the lithospheric strength is just right. Another factor could be the temperature gradient (1) across the core-mantle boundary and (2) across the lithosphere. Here's the best way I can think of to explain this (1) On Earth, we know that out core is convecting because we have a magnetic field. A convecting mantle helps the lithospheric plates moves (though it is unclear if the convection mechanism is whole-mantle or two-layer).
